text: the rescue team has just been told an
orangutan is trapped near a burning
forest
all the land around her is burning if we
don't rescue and serve her today she
will probably burn alive their
rehabilitation center itself has been
cloaked in thick smoke for months and
many of the younger orangutangs are
getting sick lots of them have the flu
up they are coughing and are also
getting fevers because of the air that
they are breathing this is where the
young orangutangs have been spending a
lot of time lately sealed away in an
attempt to try and protect them from the
toxic haze to ease the boredom they're
given toys to play with while they wait
inside the fires are coming dangerously
close to their home this area just 800
meters away manager denny cornea one
says they're on high alert this could
burn again this is peatland and we know
when it's dried out it very easily
catches fire he suspects the area was
deliberately burnt to make way for a
palm oil plantation and he's calling on
the police to investigate I'm very angry
and frustrated this is a protected area
the orangutan is our protected species
the president says the government is
fighting a war against the haze so why
are these fires still happening the haze
was too thick for the rescue team to
find the stranded orangutan they would
try again in the hope that they can find
her alive and bring her back here but if
fires get closer they will have to
evacuate all these orangutangs to a
safer place rebecca henskee BBC news
central kalimantan
